articles.headline: Jewish Viewers Find a Refuge in Fox News
articles.snippet: The network’s unflinching support for Israel in its fight against Hamas has put the conservative network in the good graces of many Jews who see other coverage of Israel as biased.
articles.abstract: The network’s unflinching support for Israel in its fight against Hamas has put the conservative network in the good graces of many Jews who see other coverage of Israel as biased.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ross Abramson, a software engineer and recent New York University graduate, had a fairly conventional news diet until recently. He regularly checked his phone for The New York Times and The Wall Street Journal. And as a Jew with an interest in Israel, he would browse a handful of outlets like The Times of Israel.

articles.headline: Blinken Urges ‘Pauses’ in Fighting to Deliver Aid for Gaza Civilians
articles.snippet: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel appeared to rebuff the Biden administration’s request, saying that any cease-fire would be contingent on the release of Israeli hostages taken by Hamas.
articles.abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel appeared to rebuff the Biden administration’s request, saying that any cease-fire would be contingent on the release of Israeli hostages taken by Hamas.
articles.lead_paragraph: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken, who traveled to Israel on Friday as the ground war against Hamas in Gaza escalated, urged protections for Palestinian noncombatants and “humanitarian pauses” in the fighting, even as he spoke of “solidarity” with Israel’s right to defend itself.
articles.byline: By Adam Entous and Thomas Fuller

articles.headline: Look, Up in the Sky! It’s a Can of Soup!
articles.snippet: Amazon’s much-hyped drone project is dropping small objects on driveways. Some customers are not sure what it delivers beyond minestrone.
articles.abstract: Amazon’s much-hyped drone project is dropping small objects on driveways. Some customers are not sure what it delivers beyond minestrone.
articles.lead_paragraph: Exactly a decade ago, Amazon revealed a program that aimed to revolutionize shopping and shipping. Drones launched from a central hub would waft through the skies delivering just about everything anyone could need. They would be fast, innovative, ubiquitous — all the Amazon hallmarks.

articles.headline: U.S. Officials Outline Steps to Israel to Reduce Civilian Casualties
articles.snippet: The measures include using smaller bombs against Hamas, U.S. officials said.
articles.abstract: The measures include using smaller bombs against Hamas, U.S. officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: U.S. officials said they have privately outlined several steps to Israel to reduce civilian casualties in its military campaign in the Gaza Strip, including using smaller bombs, when going after Hamas leaders and infrastructure.
articles.byline: By Adam Entous, Eric Schmitt and Julian E. Barnes

articles.headline: Across the Echo Chamber, a Quiet Conversation About War and Race
articles.snippet: When two acquaintances in Atlanta sat down to find common ground on the Israel-Hamas war, they found themselves in a painful conversation about race, power and whose suffering is recognized.
articles.abstract: When two acquaintances in Atlanta sat down to find common ground on the Israel-Hamas war, they found themselves in a painful conversation about race, power and whose suffering is recognized.
articles.lead_paragraph: Samara Minkin was already feeling rattled when she saw a Facebook post from one of her children’s former teachers seven days after Hamas killed or kidnapped more than 1,600 people in Israel.

articles.headline: A Secret War, Strange New Wounds and Silence From the Pentagon
articles.snippet: Many U.S. troops who fired vast numbers of artillery rounds against the Islamic State developed mysterious, life-shattering mental and physical problems. But the military struggled to understand what was wrong.
articles.abstract: Many U.S. troops who fired vast numbers of artillery rounds against the Islamic State developed mysterious, life-shattering mental and physical problems. But the military struggled to understand what was wrong.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Javier Ortiz came home from a secret mission in Syria, the ghost of a dead girl appeared to him in his kitchen. She was pale and covered in chalky dust, as if hit by an explosion, and her eyes stared at him with a glare as dark and heavy as oil.
articles.byline: By Dave Philipps and Matthew Callahan

articles.headline: Why Banks Are Suddenly Closing Down Customer Accounts
articles.snippet: Surprised individuals and small-business owners can’t pay rent or make payroll, and no one ever explains what they did wrong.
articles.abstract: Surprised individuals and small-business owners can’t pay rent or make payroll, and no one ever explains what they did wrong.
articles.lead_paragraph: The reasons vary, but the scene that plays out is almost always the same.
articles.byline: By Ron Lieber and Tara Siegel Bernard

articles.headline: What the Golden Gate Is (Finally) Doing About Suicides
articles.snippet: After years of pressure from victims’ families, the installation of $217 million in steel netting is almost complete.
articles.abstract: After years of pressure from victims’ families, the installation of $217 million in steel netting is almost complete.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was May 27, 1937, the opening day for a stunning new suspension bridge across a gap in the California coastline known as the Golden Gate. Before cars were allowed on the crossing, an estimated 200,000 people celebrated between the bridge’s four-foot-high rails, more than 200 feet above the water.
articles.byline: By John Branch and Jim Wilson

articles.headline: Another Google Antitrust Battle Reaches Court in Epic Games Case
articles.snippet: The Fortnite creator accuses Google of stifling app competition, a challenge on top of a federal suit claiming the tech giant abuses its search dominance.
articles.abstract: The Fortnite creator accuses Google of stifling app competition, a challenge on top of a federal suit claiming the tech giant abuses its search dominance.
articles.lead_paragraph: For two months, Google has squared off against the Justice Department in court in Washington over claims that the company is abusing its dominant position in online search and advertising to crush rivals, a high-stakes antitrust case that could reshape the world’s most popular search engine. Now, it’s facing another legal challenge closer to home.
articles.byline: By Kellen Browning and Nico Grant

articles.headline: Job Action Against Tesla Puts Sweden’s Unions in Spotlight
articles.snippet: The automaker’s mechanics in Sweden are striking for a collective agreement, and dockworkers say they will support the battle. Tesla is expected to join the talks on Monday.
articles.abstract: The automaker’s mechanics in Sweden are striking for a collective agreement, and dockworkers say they will support the battle. Tesla is expected to join the talks on Monday.
articles.lead_paragraph: More than a week after Tesla mechanics in Sweden began a strike to compel the U.S. automaker to accept a collective labor agreement, union officials said Tesla representatives would meet with the union on Monday.

articles.headline: Trump Leads in 5 Critical States as Voters Blast Biden, Times/Siena Poll Finds
articles.snippet: Voters in battleground states said they trusted Donald J. Trump over President Biden on the economy, foreign policy and immigration, as Mr. Biden’s multiracial base shows signs of fraying.
articles.abstract: Voters in battleground states said they trusted Donald J. Trump over President Biden on the economy, foreign policy and immigration, as Mr. Biden’s multiracial base shows signs of fraying.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Biden is trailing Donald J. Trump in five of the six most important battleground states one year before the 2024 election, suffering from enormous doubts about his age and deep dissatisfaction over his handling of the economy and a host of other issues, new polls by The New York Times and Siena College have found.

articles.headline: After Lewiston Shooting, Maine’s Deaf Community Seeks to Rise Above, Again
articles.snippet: The attack, in which four of the 18 people killed were Deaf, resurfaced previous traumas and came after decades of efforts to be recognized.
articles.abstract: The attack, in which four of the 18 people killed were Deaf, resurfaced previous traumas and came after decades of efforts to be recognized.
articles.lead_paragraph: As residents across Maine sat riveted to their TVs on Oct. 27, waiting anxiously for updates on the manhunt for a gunman who had killed 18 people, state officials opened their news briefing with a stern directive for the cameras in the room.
articles.byline: By Jenna Russell and Amelia Nierenberg

articles.headline: U.S. Officials Fear American Guns Ordered by Israel Could Fuel West Bank Violence
articles.snippet: Israel wants 24,000 assault rifles. Itamar Ben-Gvir, a far-right minister overseeing the police, has given rifles to civilians and is forming “security squads.”
articles.abstract: Israel wants 24,000 assault rifles. Itamar Ben-Gvir, a far-right minister overseeing the police, has given rifles to civilians and is forming “security squads.”
articles.lead_paragraph: An Israeli government request for 24,000 assault rifles from the United States is drawing scrutiny from American lawmakers and some State Department officials who fear the weapons might end up in the hands of settlers and civilian militias trying to force Palestinians from land in the West Bank, where violence has been surging, U.S. officials say.
articles.byline: By Edward Wong and Patrick Kingsley

articles.headline: More Semiconductors, Less Housing: China’s New Economic Plan
articles.snippet: Policymakers, wary of inciting reckless borrowing in real estate, are instead investing heavily in factories and trying to help indebted local governments.
articles.abstract: Policymakers, wary of inciting reckless borrowing in real estate, are instead investing heavily in factories and trying to help indebted local governments.
articles.lead_paragraph: China’s political leaders, under pressure to support the country’s fragile recovery, are slowly steering the economy on a new course. No longer able to rely on real estate and local debt to drive growth, they are instead investing more heavily in manufacturing and increasing borrowing by the central government.

articles.headline: Cricket Gives a Nation Bowed by Violence a Reason to Stand Tall
articles.snippet: Afghanistan’s cricket team has won big games and many fans in an international competition, in a stark contrast to the pariah status of its government.
articles.abstract: Afghanistan’s cricket team has won big games and many fans in an international competition, in a stark contrast to the pariah status of its government.
articles.lead_paragraph: The national flag they play under no longer exists officially. The anthem they stand for at the beginning of every game belongs to a republic that was toppled two years ago.
articles.byline: By Mujib Mashal and Atul Loke

articles.headline: Tech Start-Ups Try to Sell a Cautious Pentagon on A.I.
articles.snippet: Shield AI, a tech start-up, already has a drone run by artificial intelligence being used by the Israeli military. But persuading the Pentagon to embrace the technology remains a big challenge.
articles.abstract: Shield AI, a tech start-up, already has a drone run by artificial intelligence being used by the Israeli military. But persuading the Pentagon to embrace the technology remains a big challenge.
articles.lead_paragraph: When he reflected on his time as a Navy SEAL serving in Afghanistan a decade ago, Brandon Tseng wondered why he and his team did not have any way to see inside buildings they were about to raid and reduce the chances of walking into a deadly trap.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton and Erin Schaff

articles.headline: Warring Billionaires, a Rogue Employee, a Divorce: One Hedge Fund’s Tale of Woe
articles.snippet: Two Sigma, the $60 billion quantitative trading firm, has been beset by troubles this year that have tarnished its image and could hurt its future.
articles.abstract: Two Sigma, the $60 billion quantitative trading firm, has been beset by troubles this year that have tarnished its image and could hurt its future.
articles.lead_paragraph: Two Sigma, one of the world’s largest hedge funds, has long prided itself on two things: the sophisticated, in-house algorithms that power its trading, and its commitment to secrecy. But recent internal troubles have forced Two Sigma to air its dirty laundry.

articles.headline: Chatbots May ‘Hallucinate’ More Often Than Many Realize
articles.snippet: When summarizing facts, ChatGPT technology makes things up about 3 percent of the time, according to research from a new start-up. A Google system’s rate was 27 percent.
articles.abstract: When summarizing facts, ChatGPT technology makes things up about 3 percent of the time, according to research from a new start-up. A Google system’s rate was 27 percent.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the San Francisco start-up OpenAI unveiled its ChatGPT online chatbot late last year, millions were wowed by the humanlike way it answered questions, wrote poetry and discussed almost any topic. But most people were slow to realize that this new kind of chatbot often makes things up.

articles.headline: Trump Indictments Haven’t Sunk His Campaign, but a Conviction Might
articles.snippet: Polls by The New York Times and Siena College show his strength in key swing states, in part because of concerns about President Biden’s age. But a conviction could be the difference in 2024.
articles.abstract: Polls by The New York Times and Siena College show his strength in key swing states, in part because of concerns about President Biden’s age. But a conviction could be the difference in 2024.
articles.lead_paragraph: For Donald J. Trump, a new set of New York Times/Siena College polls captures a stunning, seemingly contradictory picture.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Swan, Ruth Igielnik and Maggie Haberman
